content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products across borders. Policies should encourage the use of international technology standards and prioritize the security and privacy of Internet users. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 promotes the use of international technology standards, respects user privacy, encourages innovation, opposes restrictions on information flow, and supports trade in Internet-related goods. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to support the use of international technology standards, protect user privacy, encourage innovation, oppose restrictions on information flow, and facilitate trade in Internet-related goods and services. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against the goal of a free and open Internet. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies contrary to a free, open Internet, including mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring the use of Internet. Certain governments are mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring the use of Internet-related tools for unauthorized access. They are also blocking or restricting Internet communications in a discriminatory manner. SEC. 4. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force must provide an annual report and action plan to the President and Congress, identifying acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access. The Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate must provide an annual report and action plan to identify acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access, including those related to Internet-related goods and services. REVIEW AND INVESTIGATION BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION AND DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" is defined in accordance with the Clayton Act. The term "antitrust laws" includes violations by nongovernmental entities and is defined in accordance with the Clayton Act, encompassing section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act for unfair competition.
